results.title: A Little fable
results.brief_description: An intriguing animated film in which symbolic representation is used instead of realistic drawings. It tells the story of Charlie, an orange boy, whose blue friend is rejected by his mother. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: A Little bit of willpower
results.creator_credit: Leanda Bunn, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Kicked out of home at the age of 15 and struggling with depression, Leanda Bunn still managed to complete her VCE, find accommodation and be independent thanks to a few very special people in her life and a lot of willpower.

results.title: A Little bit in all of us
results.creator_credit: Brian Hannant, South Australian Film Corporation and Bosisto Productions
results.brief_description: This film encourages people to enjoy the solitude and splendour of our national parks, while taking precautions to avoid destruction and havoc. A typically Australian family, the Innes, are mildly satirised as they unwillingly get into a situation that took public money to rectify. Three major problem areas are covered: bushfires started by campers, people trapped on cliffs and people lost in the bush. The fact that it is costly and difficult to save people from these dangerous situations is highlighted.

results.title: A Link with our past
results.brief_description: There was a time when the cable car was the pride of many major cities in the Western World, but that was when the pace of life was much slower. However, when major cities started to expand, it became apparent that the demand for some form of short-haul transportation could not be ignored. A young engineer named George Smith Duncan has successfully built a cable tramway in New Zealand. He later moved to Melbourne where he would eventually build the worlds largest cable tram network.

results.title: A Likely story! = Quelle histoire!
results.creator_credit: Koos Hillenaar, Kohill Productions and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: An animated refresher course on Canadian history for people who may be a little rusty on what happened in the centuries preceding Confederation. Cartoon animation gives life, substance and humor to the characters who have crossed the stage of Canadian history, from Columbus to Macdonald, treating them with a satirical wit that would be impossible in any learned treatise.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Koos Hillenaar, Kohill Productions and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: A Light in nature
results.creator_credit: Ramsay Short, Stuart Legg and Shell Film Unit
results.brief_description: Made on the occasion of the tercentenary of the Royal Society, this film describes the history and achievements of scientific research and indicated what may lie ahead on the borders of science. Studies on the living cell and in radio astronomy are taken as examples of fields in which significant advances may be expected in the future.

results.title: A Life Worth Living
results.brief_description: Presents hypothetical case studies of newly born severely handicapped children. A panel of eminent members of the medical and legal professions are asked what their decisions would be in these situations when one human being has the power of life and death over another

results.title: A Life worth living
results.creator_credit: Michael Latham, Antony Jay, Peter Robinson and Video Arts
results.brief_description: Recapitulates points made in the first four parts of the series to show how a community progresses from a state of subsistence to surplus: then, using animation and documentary footage, shows how the surplus produced by a worker is in effect swapped by him for all the other things he needs but does not produce himself. Narrated by Judy Cornwell, Desmond Carrington.

results.title: A Life on the farm
results.creator_credit: Oz Sanderson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Oz Sanderson grew up on his farm with his two brothers during the Great Depression. His dad signed a consent form for him to join the army. While Oz was determined to serve as a pilot, the farm was always in his heart and he was more than happy to return to it after the war ended.

results.title: A Life of perfection
results.brief_description: Why does a nun cut herself off from the world in the Service of God? What are the difficulties and joys of living closely together in a Convent? How do nuns try to live a “life of perfection”? In this film photographed at the Roman Catholic Convent of the Sisters of the Assumption, London, and the Anglican Community of the Sisters of the Love of God, Oxford, nuns explain their attitude to their work and the world outside.
